headline: The Best Meatballs
description: Learn how to make meatballs with this recipe that combines ground beef, veal, and pork, with garlic, parsley, and cheese for the best meatballs ever!

video.description: See how to make amazing meatballs with ground beef, veal, and pork.
video.name: The Best Meatballs

name: The Best Meatballs
recipeIngredient: 1.5 tablespoons chopped Italian flat leaf parsley
salt and ground black pepper to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Combine beef, veal, and pork in a large bowl. Mix in cheese, eggs, garlic, parsley, salt, and pepper.
Add bread crumbs and slowly mix in water, 1/2 cup at a time, until mixture is moist but still holds its shape (I usually use about 1 1/4 cups of water); shape into meatballs.
Heat olive oil in a large skillet; add meatballs in batches and cook until browned on all sides, slightly crisp, and cooked through, about 10 to 15 minutes. Drain on paper towels.

review.reviewBody: I've been using this recipe for years. Literally. It's fantastic! And shared it many times over. I too use whatever meat combo that's good, never the veal or pork. I also air fry them on high for 12 minutes. Makes a nice crust on the outside and pink in the middle. I finish cooking the inside in the sauce. I double it up and give a few batches to family. Big day for them! They love it!!! There's enough leftover for meatball samiches a few days later too. Another big day for us haha. My tip - you need to be heavy handed with the seasoning. There's a lot of meat in that bowl so hit it generously! Under seasoned = bland.
Very nice. I used an air fryer at 400 for 12 minutes instead of the frying pan. Nice and crispy on the outside.

Best meatballs there are. Mine were a little on the large size so it took slightly more oil in the pan. Ground veal can be a challenge to find. Found some at Publix. This recipe is very much like Raos. It's worth the time. Btw, I used bagged bread crumbs.

I loved this recipe ,I omitted the veal only. I didn't have any available I did not use bread crumb's also. I did broil the meatballs and finished them in a homemade sauce . Plated the dish with fresh grated parmigiana & fresh Parsley. It came out great.
These turned out so good; I will use in Marinara sauce as a meatball bake with mozzarella cheese melted on top. Recommend!
I took others advice and baked my meatballs. I also only used ground beef and Italian sausage and they still turned out fantastic!

Excellent. Made it twice the first time 4 stars. The second time I substituted, breadcrumbs for stale bread, Italian pork sausage for ground pork and used an air fryer. Labor & cleanup much less, taste improved. TRY YOUR AIR FRYER!
I used 1 lb ground beef, 1 lb of sweet ground italian sausage. I didn't the water and it urned out awesome! Scooped meat balls with ice cream scooper. To make same size.
Loved this recipe. Used beef and pork - no veal. Added fresh basil and to one batch I added a small handful of mozzarella cheese and those were delicious!!!!!!

Rating this recipe was hard. If I was to go by the actual recipe, I would give it a 1 at best. Frying the meatballs was a huge mistake. The cheese melts and makes a big gooey mess in the pan. If you make your meatballs too big, they are not going to get all way way done. With all the moisture in them, they are going to have a nasty tendency to fall apart. And worst of all is they come out looking and tasting very greasy. Luckily I did half the batch in the oven at 400 and those turned out way better. The ones in the oven warrant a 4 or 5. They were really good. So I split the difference and gave the recipe a 3. So do yourself a huge favor and dont try to fry them. You will regret it.
I couldn't find ground veal so I used 1 lb each of ground beef and pork. I used panko crumbs and Milk instead of water, and baked them at 375 for 30 minutes. Excellent.

I followed the recipe to the T. Except I baked them instead of frying (350 total 30 minutes, I flipped them after 15 min). These were very good and my ex in-laws are from Italy. Update: I had an old recipe of meatballs from my Italian relatives. I liked the spices from the old one but the texture from this new one. I added one teaspoon each of salt, garlic salt and onion salt, and 1/2 tsp of pepper and they were perfect.
Very good meatball recipe, I just baked it rather than fried (for next time I need to remember to put wax paper).

I did it verbatim the first time. So so. Next time I used milk instead of water and added salt and pepper and a dash of onion powder, and a pinch of thyme. Instead of frying (way too much fat that absorbs because of the breadcrumbs), I baked on a parchment lined baking sheet for 20 minutes at 375 and they came out great.
The recipe is what I have used for years. The only thing I do differently is I use a trey with a rack in the oven at 350• degrees for forty five minutes and put in my sauce. Easy to clean.

I like the oven rack idea, here! The art + science of meatballs. Too dry and they are hard. Too wet/mushy and they break up. But two things are for sure: stale bread is for purists, yes. But the step-up in flavor from Progresso Italian breadcrumbs is unmistakeable. Wouldn't do without...and all 3 meats for best taste. Secondly: not cheap, dear reader, but: Locatelli Romano cheese, fresh grated. THIS, is the jewelry! Along with fresh garlic and parsley, your meatballs will completely level up with these two additions. Italian GOLD!!
Delicious recipe! I couldn’t find ground veal or pork so I used an Italian seasoned ground turkey and they came out delicious!

Recipe was fantastic. I used milk instead of water. And if you use an ice cream scoop to make the meatballs they are uniform and will cook better. Flatten the mixin the scoop so you don’t end up with larger than u want. ( HALF A SCOOP)
Left out the water!

I changed it up a little. I used 80/20 beef, ground Turkey and bulk Italian sausage. 50/30/20 mix. I used plain bread crumbs and tomato juice for my liquid. I baked mine and put them under my broiler for about 5 minutes to brown them. Then, into my homemade gravy (3 cans of crushed tomatoes, can of paste, fresh chopped parsley and basil, minced garlic, salt n pepper. My guests loved them. Swore I’ve got Italian blood on my veins.

I am amazed -- this is the exact recipe that my Italian mother always used!! I have always followed her recipe. My large Italian family always said my mother made the best meatballs. I'm so glad to see it in print.
I followed it exactly & was very pleased with the result.

I made this and it is very good. I tried it because of the water. I normally use milk, soak the stale bread cubed in it then squeeze out the bread. The rest is exactly the same. I think the milk adds a little more moth feel. This is only my opinion. But follow this exact recipe and you will not be disappointed at all. Retired Chef di Cucina, Mangia Fresco, Napoli, Italia
Perfect and very easy
Best and easiest meatball recipe. Just like Mom made. I used all ground beef and fresh Parmesan this time because that’s what I had on hand.
This was the BEST meatball recipe I’ve ever had. I made it for a crowd and they all LOVED it. Thank you!
Love this! The only thing I did different was I only used 1 cup of water and used ground beef only for the meat and I baked them at 350 degrees for 30 mins.
I did everything but the oil and turned out great.. air fried them on about 320 for 8 minutes on both sides
Added 8 oz tomotoe paste to thicken up suace.
good simple recipe. I have used it before!
I don't like meatballs. I made these for a family member. Milk, panko, no olive oil, was the only substitution. Baked at 375 for 25 minutes DELICIOUSLY moist. 5 stars all the way.
This was one of the most simple and amazing recipes I have ever tried. I usually don’t use recipes for meatballs because they are so simple but I am so happy I tried this

Great, except I substituted more pork instead of veal and simmered in spaghetti sauce for 4+ hours vs frying. Made a meatball app by throwing some in a cast iron pan with sauce and mozzarella at 425 for 10-15min.
I used milk instead of water Very nice will make again
Added more fresh garlic, basil and oregano. Only 1/2 cup water. Easy came out perfect 🥰

Excellent. I don't change the recipe except for baking vs frying. I have used a pound of ground pork if I am unable to get the veal. Add to pound of beef. Baking is so much easier. Use Foil lined sheets for golf sized meatballs . 20 mins at 350. Easier to pull meatballs off sheet if you place cookie sheets cooled down into freezer for 10 mins . Pop them off and place extra meatballs in freezer bag with sauce. Quick dinner in the future with pasta or sandwich.
I made these meatballs last night and they were perfect! Very flavorful and juicy. Highly recommend!

Great recipe! I added some chopped prosciuto and 1/2 tsp pepper flakes.
Do not overhandle meatballs! Thanks for sharing.

First time making these and I’ll definitely be making them again! Had no veal on hand. Used lean ground beef and delicious locally made pork sausage. Otherwise, made as written. Tried a reviewer’s suggestion to bake some of them. Baked on parchment @ 350 until browned. Both fried and baked were very, very good! Thanks for an excellent recipe!
The best meatballs!

These really are the best meatballs. Adding the water is the key to their tenderness. I must say I only used equal parts of ground beef and ground pork, no veal, otherwise I made the recipe exactly as written. Truly delicious!
This is the best meatball recipe bar none! I always have to add more bread to get the consistency right but they always end up perfect. I use my deep fryer instead of pan frying, but that’s just me.
Instead of the water ADD BEEF BROTH, Gives it a better richer taste. Grand Mother would Kill me if she knew I told people.

I made these twice. Once following the recipe to a T and the next how I would have made them. My findings are as follows: too much cheese, cut it in half. Not enough garlic double it. It is ridiculous to add a "salt and pepper to taste" measurement in a raw food item... can't taste until you cook it creating waste. for those curious I did a teaspoon Kosher salt and 1/2 a teaspoon fine ground black pepper. What's with the water at all? I've never used it in any of my meat balls... I'm lost there. And don't deep fry ground meats they with fall apart. I used a 1/2 table spoon of olive oil in a 12 inch cast iron skillet and they turned out beautifully. Also optional I added a small spring of fresh thyme and a teaspoon of crushed red pepper. While a prefer to back them, pan frying worked pretty well as long as your not submerging the poor meat in oil. I cooked to 140 then added to a marinara sauce and was perfection. the first batch I cooked to 155 (health code standard in co for ground meats but over done in my opinion) and they fell apart and melted
I made the recipe pretty much as published, except I didn't have any PORK SAUSAGE SO I USED "JOHNSONVILLE" BEEF BEER BRATS (I often use Brats for my pork sausage). I think they turned out very good
Absolutely delicious!! Made double batch, baked instead of fried. Love these

As a personal chef/home cook, these meatballs were great! The aroma, the flavor all there. Shared some meat balls and my 'marinararribiata sauce' with my new neighbors and they loved it all. The only thing I changed to this recipe is that I added small diced yellow onion and mixed it all together. Thanks for this recipe-it's a keeper!

Very good and moist! 
I made it just as written--very good. And I also made it using 3T almond flour instead of the bread (for a friend of mine who can't eat grains) and added an onion. Even better! Thanks for recipe
Very Good, I added some chopped onions to the mix

Substituted Italian sausage and turned out wonderful. Excellent texture.
Thanks.
These are THE BEST tasting meatballs. Followed the recipe and my family loves them.
For more tender meatballs use milk in place of water

I have been making this recipe for over 52 years and everyone, everyone says I make the best meatballs in the world.I cook them in the oven on baking sheets with olive oil, because I usually make more than 100 at a time for family gatherings. The only difference is I soak stale bread in milk and add it to the mixture instead of using bread crumbs as the bread crumbs made the meat a too dense. One trick I use is to take a thumb nail sized piece of mixture and put it in the microwave for 30 seconds to taste for enough Romano and or salt. Great recipe!

I made this without veal because veal is a very inhuman and cruel industry from birth to death. I used beef and pork and it was delicious. Yes, I know beef and pork cause death but not within months of birth and in humane conditions.

I made these with all beef because that’s what I had at home. Otherwise stayed true to the recipe. They were really really good. After 27 years of marriage just making meatballs on autopilot, these were a nice refreshing change. The kids raved about them !

Yay! I finally found a meatball recipe that is actually really good. It even worked with just turkey. The only thing I did different was to use milk (instead of water) and cook the meatballs in the sauce like others had suggested. Thanks so much!!
Very delicious. The outside was nice and seared while the inside was creamy and full of flavor. No variations were made from the recipe.
Delicious meatballs! I bake not fry as well.
These meatballs are fantastic! Once I made with all beef and they were just as good!! Thick recipe is a keeper!
Very yummy

They were extremely wet and after cooking they felt like I was eating raw hamburger. Don't use water. 
Better luck next time.

Delicious. I use a little less water and you have to play around with the amount of cheese you want but the base is there. Also, instead of making my own, I use half regular breadcrumbs and half panko. 

At a recent family dinner, my nephew said, “These are the best meatballs I’ve ever had.” Much to the chagrin of my Italian mother seated across from him :)

I've seen this recipe for awhile & decided to try it. The amount of water seemed ridiculous but I went on faith & made it exactly as it is written. When I made them, they were very wet but I kept going. Well, of course, when I browned them, most fell apart. I put them all in sauce & the meal was saved. It wasn't meatballs any longer when done, just a meat sauce which, BTW, was very good but there were no more meatballs. Don't do it. I learned my lesson.
The best meatballs! I used 1 cup of breadcrumbs, 1 tsp of salt, and added a little milk at a time to the mixture until it became the right texture.
Absolutely the best meatballs I’ve ever had!!!

This really is a great recipe. I didn’t have veal, but did use the pork and beef. Not crazy about the salt and pepper to taste in any recipe, since you can’t taste until you cook one, but that minor. I used all the water and fried them. Although I do sometimes bake my meatballs My mom always fried them and they were always a hit. I fried them this time to get a nice “crust” and they are finishing in the sauce. They are moist and tasty. Will make again.
No Romano used Parmesan, but they are still fantastic.
awesome
Even with panko and canned Parmesan this was delicious. I used Italian sausage instead of veal and baked them instead of frying them and was very impressed. Definitely a keeper of a recipe.
This Is The Best Thing Ever. The Guys Really Get At Me To Make This All The Time.
Wait! Wait! Use an ice cream scoop and scoop them into cupcake cups in cupcake pans. 325 degrees for 45 minutes. makes 2 dozen.

My first time making homemade meatballs and they turned out GREAT! The recipe wasn’t difficult at all. After my second time making them (to perfect), I may try the mixture with Italian sausage in place of the ground pork. Thank you for sharing!

Recipe is a good base and I made the following changes based off others reviews. 
Use 1 Lb. of each meat.
Add an extra 1/4 cup of cheese and bread crumbs.
Generous handful of chopped spinach instead of parsley.
Just a splash of water.
Cook in the oven at 325 for 25-30 minutes.

Love this recipe. I have made it several times. Highly recommend oven baking as pan frying makes such a mess. Good part about pan frying is you do get to eat all those yummy crumbs. But too much work. Oven from now on.

So good! I substituted Italian sausage for the ground pork. I did pan fry the meatballs (in small batches) in olive oil until crispy on all sides, I then placed the meatballs in tomato sauce and simmered for several hours until they were fully cooked. Crispy on the outside and super moist on the inside! Truly the best meatballs I’ve ever had.

So I did choose to fry these meatballs. I used a pound of extra lean 95-5 ground beef (this keeps them from falling apart) and a pound of ground pork. I subbed fresh parsley for dried and used Italian seasoned bread crumbs. I wanted spicy meatballs so I added red pepper flakes to the mixture. I put canola oil a 12in frying pan on the highest heat and coated my meatballs in flour. I browned them all the way around. They turned out moist, crispy, and perfect. I let them rest and added them to my sauce an hour before serving.
Finally! After searching for a meatball recipe my whole family loves! I cooked them in my air fryer. So fast and easy!!

I had been making a chunky type of meatball for years, until my 2 year-old grandson wouldn't eat them, and preferred the smoother type from the supermarket. So I went looking for a new recipe, and this is it! I cheat and use packaged Italian season bread crumbs; I brown them on the stove in olive oil and then drop them in my sauce for 90 minutes. Always a hit!
Yummy!!! I used parm cheese and added oregano and it was delicious!

These are the perfect texture if cooked properly. Don't overcook or they'll be dry! I found them not to be flavorful enough, so I used parmesan cheese instead of Romano, doubled the garlic, and added a big pinch of red pepper flakes. Will be making again!

I only used 1 cup Italian bread crumbs, I seared them on each side in a combination of olive oil and garlic ghee oil and then I put them in a pot of simmering marinara sauce , best meatballs I've ever made

This is Raos restaurant recipe basically to a T except that they say bread crumbs not stale Italian bread. I do agree that if you have an amazing Italian bread, it would make for a nice crumb addition. I do add Luke warm water or even some milk. Obviously you can play around with the amount of garlic, salt n pepper to your taste, but I’m adamant on the fresh parsley. I’d even say you can adds little more than that. Add raisins or even pieces of fresh good quality mozzarella to the inside for a nice surprise. These are basically how my mom and most Italian people make them. It’s a great recipe.
Best meatballs ever! I use all beef and cook them in oven and then pop them in the sauce.

So good!! Best I’ve ever had! I had to improvise a little with what I had on hand, but they turned out great! I used a roll of Bob Evans sausage instead of the pork and veal. And I used Italian bread crumbs. 5 star recipe!!

good recipe, my great grandpa is feom a small town outside of Sicily, my grandma always made a sweet sauce and cooked the meatballs in the sauce all day, no pre cooking. I find that this really makes a meatball, I have had others and they are good, but cooking the way Grandma did all day in the sauce no question! also I use a 90% lean ground beef so you dont have much in the way of grease. final notes if you dont have bread crumbs and dont want to wait pull apart the ends on Italian sandwich bread and let sit while you get everything ready, works good too. I dont use water, add either sauce or milk. I use sauce and it brings out the flavor even more!!

I love these! Depending on the size of my meatballs, I bake them approximate 25- 40 minutes at 300-350. 

I let them cool mostly, and then I do briefly drop them in some hot olive oil. It crisps the outsides up a bit, and gives extra yummy flavor.

This is an amazing recipe, I was worried about adding water to the meat, but it actually turned out amazing and the meatballs where nice and moist. I cooked the meatballs in the oven on parchment paper For a healthier alternative, and they where perfect!
I am stunned how great these turned out. Like many others, I only used ground beef and thought the recipe would suffer but it did not. Best meatballs I have ever had!
I made these exactly to the recipe, except I baked them instead of frying. Not impressed. They need more spices. I found them to be very bland.
Best Meatballs I've ever made!
Darn good meatballs.

Overall it was not terrible. What I would do next time is maybe add more breadcrumbs since the meatballs kept falling apart. You could really taste the pork flavor in it which I did not think you could but like I said overall it was good.
Perfect, easy, super tasty. Will make again and again. Thx.

I’d post a picture but there is none left to show you all I made 2 recipes for my son n his family love meatballs n the rest like crumble meat I can send you a pix of the crumbed meat !! All I heard was these are the very best meatballs I’ve ever had over n over I did as suggested I baked in a rack and I n a oven 325 they were done in no time held together wonderful, none fell apart so easy to do ! Thank you

It IS the best meatball recipe I have tried, and that includes Emeril's Big Boys. I used beef and pork, not the veal. And I baked them . I finished them up by dropping them in the sauce. They were a very good texture and great taste. Excellent! It's a keeper.

1) Needs salt

2) needs a lot less bread crumbs

3) needs onion

I did all those and still lacked a little flavour

i think for that much meat remove the bread crumbs and add 1/4 cup of plain flour to help bind the egg and meat and 1 and half teaspoons of salt, i put in 1 teaspoon and wasn't enough.

Try that and that will be the best. Herbs not really needed in this

Definitely not the best meatballs around,but they are easy enough to fix to your own taste.I always cook a little piece in the griddle to make sure the meat is well seasoned, and found these too bland for my taste so I added the spices I like until it was right for my taste. Needless to say, I happily ate my spaghetti and meatballs!
I only use all beef. This is a pretty basic recipe
Too much water, not enough garlic and spices. I would add oregano, 1/2 t chili powder, cardamom. Garam masala or berbera would also work. Something, but no veal.
